alert.note: Alert for Walsh (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks (Northeastern North Dakota and Northwestern Minnesota)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 25 at 11:44AM CDT until April 29 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Eastern ND and Grand Forks
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Dakota... Sheyenne River near Kindred affecting Richland and Cass Counties. Sheyenne River at Lisbon affecting Ransom County. Goose River at Hillsboro affecting Traill County. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Dakota... Maple River near Mapleton (South of I-94) affecting Cass County. Maple River near Enderlin affecting Ransom and Cass Counties. Forest River at Minto affecting Walsh County. Sheyenne River Diversion at West Fargo affecting Cass County. Sheyenne River at Harwood affecting Cass County. Pembina River at Walhalla affecting Pembina and Cavalier Counties. Pembina River at Neche affecting Pembina County. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY FRIDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Forest River at Minto. * WHEN...Until early Friday morning. * IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, MODERATE FLOOD. During high flow, river may bypass Minto to the south and flow into Lake Ardoch. Urban flooding begins. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM CDT Monday the stage was 8.1 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall to 8.0 feet and then begin rising this afternoon. It will then rise again to 8.2 feet just after midnight tonight. It will fall below flood stage Wednesday evening to 4.5 feet and then begin rising early Friday afternoon. It will then rise again to 5.9 feet Sunday evening. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 6.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Safety message - Turn around, don`t drown. Don`t travel through flooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
